docs.title: Documentation Guide
docs.text: Welcome to the official documentation for the documentation-default! This guide will walk you through everything you need to know—from setting up the environment to deploying and updating your documentation.

docs.title: Get Started
docs.text:
To get started right away, head to the Setup Guide and follow the step-by-step instructions.

For contributions or questions, feel free to open an issue or pull request on GitHub.

docs.title: Public Repository
docs.text: If your repository is public, you can easily deploy your documentation using GitHub Pages. Here's how:

docs.title: 1. MkDocs Configuration
docs.text:
Make sure to run mkdocs from the config path:

mkdocs build -f mkdocs.yml

Inside mkdocs.yml, confirm:

site_dir: site

Use the built-in deploy command:

mkdocs gh-deploy

Make sure site/ is ignored on .gitignore (you don’t need to commit it).

docs.title: 2. Navigate to Repository Settings
docs.text: Go to your repository and click on the Settings tab.

docs.title: 3. Open the Pages Settings
docs.text: Scroll down the left-hand sidebar and select Pages.

docs.title: 4. Configure the Source
docs.text:
Under the Build and deployment section:

  • Set the Source to Deploy from a branch
  • Select the gh-pages branch
  • Click Save

After saving, GitHub will automatically trigger a GitHub Action that builds and deploys your documentation.

docs.title: Private Repository
docs.text:
If your repository is private, GitHub Pages might not be an option depending on your plan. In this case, you can run the documentation locally.

mkdocs serve

This will start a development server. Open your browser and visit:

http://127.0.0.1:8000

You'll be able to preview and navigate through the documentation in real time.

docs.title: Further Examples
docs.text: To see a real implementation example using this setup, check out the documentation inside the FilterComp project.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Ensure your system has the following installed:

  • Python 3.10+
  • pip
  • Git

docs.title: Cloning the Project
docs.text:
Clone the repository to your local machine: 

git clone https://github.com/Safe-Solutions-Engenharia/documentation-default.git 
cd documentation-default

docs.title: Creating a Virtual Enviroment
docs.text:
Create and activate a virtual environment:

WindowsLinux/macOS 
python -m venv venv
venv\Scripts\activate

python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate

docs.title: Installing Dependencies
docs.text:
Install dependencies listed in requirements.txt:

pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Understanding Project Structure
docs.text:
documentation-default/
├── docs/
│   ├── index.md
│   └── assets/
│       └── images/
├── mkdocs.yml
├── requirements.txt
└── README.md

The docs/ folder contains all Markdown source files from each page of the documentation. The mkdocs.yml file contains the configuration for the documentation name, theme, navigation and plugings.

docs.title: Editing Documentation
docs.text:
All documentation is written in Markdown (.md). For example, index.md might look like:

index.md
# Welcome

This is the homepage of your MkDocs documentation.

Always use Markdown syntax to add headings, links, images, tables, and more.

docs.title: Adding Pages and Navigation
docs.text:
In mkdocs.yml, define the order of the documentation structure:

mkdocs.yml
nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - Setup Guide: setup.md
  - Editing Guide: update-documentation.md
  - Deploy Example: deployment.md

docs.title: Further Reading
docs.text: To learn more about specific plugins and Markdown syntax, check out the the mkdocs documentation.
